thread.title: Hawks take care of business; set up Trinity showdown
thread.title_full: Hawks take care of business; set up Trinity showdown

title: Hawks take care of business; set up Trinity showdown
text:
Hawks take care of business; set up Trinity showdown Saturday, October 24, 2015 Comments 
MARIETTA — The Heritage School put its past road struggles at Dominion Christian to rest in a big way on Friday, scoring on each of its first six possessions and cruising to a 49-14 rout to set up a showdown with Trinity Christian next week for second place in GISA Region 1-AAA and a first-round playoff game at home. 
Heritage’s win coupled with Trinity’s loss at home to Loganville put the Coweta rivals even in the 1-AAA standings at 4-1 heading into the final week of the regular season. 
The Hawks took care of business on both sides of the ball while hounding the Knights en route to five sacks and nine tackles for loss between defenders Jake Trammell and Jay Macke. 
Macke added a 30-yard interception return to open the third quarter after Heritage (5-4) built a 35-0 lead at half- time while finishing with four tackles for loss and two sacks. 
The Hawks scored on all five possessions in the first half while being led by Hamp Smith’s 146 yards and three touchdowns on 16 carries. 
Quarterback Jacob Bryant was equally effective when needed, finishing 5-for-7 for 116 yards with a pair of scoring throws to Matt Henson. 
Henson’s first touchdown reception on a screen pass for 40 yards gave Heritage a 14-0 lead in the closing minute of the first quarter. 
Heritage then used three long runs from midfield to set up Smith’s second touchdown from 1-yard out and a 21-0 lead. 
Trammell then picked up two of his three sacks on Dominion’s next possession, setting up another scoring drive for the Hawks that ended when Matt Burns raced around the end for a 25-yard touchdown. 
Heritage’s offense closed out the first half on a 45-yard scoring strike from Bryant to Henson. 
After Macke’s interception, Smith closed out the scoring for the Hawks under a running clock on another 1-yard touchdown run. More
